Pensacola, Florida, United States | instrument = [[Human voice|Vocals]], [[piano]] | genre = [[Classic female blues]], [[jazz]] | occupation = [[Singing|Singer]], [[pianist]] | years_active = 1920s–2000 | label = | associated_acts = [[Billie Pierce]] | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Ida Goodson''' (November 23, 1909 – January 5, 2000){{cite web|url=http://pineyflatwoodsgirl.blogspot.com/2007/09/ida-goodson-florida-blueswoman.html |title=Piney Flatwoods Girl: Ida Goodson: Florida Blueswoman |publisher=Pineyflatwoodsgirl.blogspot.com |date=2007-09-08 |accessdate=2014-01-26}} was an [[United States|American]] [[classic female blues]] and [[jazz]] [[singing|singer]] plus [[pianist]]. ==Biography== Goodson was born in [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]], [[Florida]], the youngest of seven sisters, six of whom survived to adulthood. Her father and mother both played piano. Her father was [[deacon]] at Pensacola's Mount Olive Baptist Church. All of the daughters received tuition in music, with the sole intention of them performing in church. Indeed, Goodson noted that the [[blues]] were banned in her house.{{cite book | first= Elizabeth | last= Grosz | year= 1995 | title= Sexy Bodies: the strange carnalities of feminism | edition= 1st | publisher= Routledge | location= London | isbn= 0-415-09802-5 | page= 234}} However, Ida, Mabel, Della, Sadie, Edna, and [[Billie Pierce|Wilhemina]] (more commonly known as Billie Pierce), all subsequently had careers in either blues or jazz. The [[Preservation Hall Jazz Band]] often had one of the Goodson sisters playing [[keyboard instrument|keyboards]]. Goodson herself played the piano for accompaniment to [[silent film]]s and at dances. The Florida Folk Archive released a recording taken at the [[Florida Folk Festival]] in 1980, comprising a [[duet (music)|duet]] between Ida and Sadie Goodson. She received a Florida Folk Heritage Award in 1987. In 2002 a stage show, ''The Goodson Sisters: Pensacola's Greatest Gift to Jazz,'' focused on Ida, Wilhemia, and Sadie Goodson. The ''Wild Women Don't Have the Blues'' [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] video included rare footage of [[Bessie Smith]] and her one-time accompanist, Goodson. [[Music journalism|Music journalist]] Chris Heim stated in the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]''; "Sprightly blues and gospel performer Ida Goodson - the scene stealer of the film - gives a stunning exhibition of the intimate connection between gospel and blues when she takes the song "[[Take My Hand, Precious Lord|Precious Lord]]" from a rich, slow gospel opening to a rollicking [[boogie-woogie]] conclusion."{{cite web|url=http://www.calliope.org/blues/blues2.html |title=The Classic Blues, 1900-1920s |publisher=Calliope.org |date=2009-01-01 |accessdate=2014-01-26}} In her senior years, Goodson played organ at several churches in Pensacola.{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p730297/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Ida Goodson|author=Chadbourne, Eugene |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=February 16, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://dhr.dos.state.fl.us/preservation/folklife/awardDetails.cfm?id=34 |title=Folk Heritage Awards Recipient: IDA GOODSON - Florida Folklife Program - Preservation - Florida Division of Historical Resources |publisher=Dhr.dos.state.fl.us |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}} An album was released by the Florida Folklife Program, ''Ida Goodson: Pensacola Piano—Florida Gulf Blues, Jazz, and Gospel.'' ==See also== *[[List of classic female blues singers]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control|VIAF=93445478}} {{Persondata | NAME = Goodson, Ida | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = [[United States|American]] [[classic female blues]] and [[jazz]] singer and pianist | DATE OF BIRTH = November 23, 1909 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Pensacola, Florida]], United States | DATE OF DEATH = January 5, 2000 | PLACE OF DEATH = Pensacola, Florida, United States }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Goodson, Ida}} [[Category:1909 births]] [[Category:2000 deaths]] [[Category:American blues pianists]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:American female singers]] [[Category:American jazz pianists]] [[Category:American jazz singers]] [[Category:Classic female blues singers]] [[Category:Musicians from Pensacola, Florida]] [[Category:Singers from Florida]] [[Category:20th-century American singers]] [[Category:Blues musicians from Florida]] [[Category:Jazz musicians from Florida]]
